article_text:
The Securities and Exchange Commission has recently come under fire for pressuring its in-house administrative-law judges to rule in its favor during agency enforcement proceedings. These are serious charges because ALJs are guaranteed independence by statute. More troubling, but largely overlooked, are the judges in federal regulatory proceedings who lack statutory independence.

They have many titles, including hearing officer, appeals officer or immigration judge. But they are often collectively referred to as...

twitter.description: In The Wall Street Journal, Kent Barnett writes that the use of administrative-law judges and administrative judges in federal regulatory agencies raises concerns about due process.
twitter.title: Due Process vs. Administrative Law

image.alt: Federal agencies control judges who decide disputes in which the agencies are a party.

These are serious charges because ALJs are guaranteed independence by statute.
